On Wednesday, 10 September 2014, 17:59, "Jeff Clune jclune@g=
mail.com [neat]" <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 


  
Hello Fred,

It turns=
 out HyperNEAT does not tend to produce modular neural networks by default.=
 See: 

	* Clune J, Beckmann BE, McKinley PK, and Ofria C (2010) Investigat=
ing whether HyperNEAT produces modular neural networks. Proceedings of the =
Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference. 635-642. http://jeffclune.=
com/publications/Clune-ModularityInHyperNEAT-Gecco2010.pdf

But it can be m=
odified to do so, in two different ways, as described in these papers:
	* H=
uizinga J, Mouret JB, Clune J (2014) Evolving Neural Networks That Are Both=
 Modular and Regular: HyperNeat Plus the Connection Cost Technique. Proceed=
ings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference. (pdf) (video)
=
	* P. Verbancsics and K.O. Stanley. Constraining connectivity to encourage =
modularity in hyperneat. In Proceedings of the 13th annual conference on Ge=
netic and evolutionary computation, pages 1483=E2=80=931490. ACM, 2011.



=
Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University o=
f Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Sep 10, 2014, at 9:45 AM, lo=
rdalveric@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

  
>
>
>It just o=
ccurred to me that HyperNEAT is an example of modular neural composition th=
at can be generalized to any arbitrary modular neural composition. The comp=
osition of TWEANNS would be, of course evaluated and evolved as a unit.
>
>=

>Have anyone tried this approach at all beyond HyperNEAT? 
>
>
>-Fred Mitc=
hell
>
>
